headline.main: Major Changes For Treatment Of Lung Cancer

docs.abstract: Lung cancer treatment is changing for first time in decades, based on research proving that chemotherapy can significantly lengthen life for many patients for whom it was previously thought to be useless; shift in care applies to about 50,000 people a year in United States with early cases of most common form of disease, non-small-cell lung cancer; in addition to surgery to remove tumor, they are now being given chemotherapy; major impetus for change came year ago, from two studies showing marked increases in survival in patients who receiveed adjuvant chemotherapy, meaning drugs were given after surgery; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in decades, doctors have begun making major changes in the treatment of lung cancer, based on research proving that chemotherapy can significantly lengthen life for many patients for whom it was previously thought to be useless. The shift in care applies to about 50,000 people a year in the United States who have early cases of the most common form of the disease, non-small-cell lung cancer, and whose tumors are removed by surgery. Many of these patients, who just a few years ago would have been treated with surgery alone, are now being given chemotherapy as well, just as it is routinely given after surgery for breast or colon cancer. The new approach has brightened a picture that was often bleak.
docs.snippet: Research proved that chemotherapy can lengthen life for many patients for whom it was previously thought to be useless.
